prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for resenting that my children see their mom as a hero?
My ex wife is a perennial fuck up. She’s been to jail on numerous occasions, had several affairs, lost more jobs than I’ve ever had, and currently lives with her mother. I was a single dad for three years to three children, years where I learned to braid hair so I could care for my daughter. I’ve remarried, and my wife and I provide the children with everything. We pay for their healthcare. We help them with their school work. We sign them up for activities they are interested in and take them to those activities. We pay for those activities. We help them with their school projects. My son is almost 16, and we will buy his car. My eight year old daughter needs braces, and we will pay for them. I ask their mother for no child support because she can’t even support herself. I don’t wish to hurt her. In fact, I’ve forgiven her for who she is and what she’s done. 
Fast forward to tonight: my daughter is entering a pageant. We’ve paid for the dress. We’ve paid the entrance fee. She gets me ask her questions she might be asked at the pageant. One was, “Who is your hero and why?” 
My daughter says, “Do you think I should say, ‘my mom?’”
I said, “ You realize you have family here? We provide for you. We registered you for this pageant. We attended the meeting. You live here full time. We care for you and love you. I know that you get to go to your mom’s every other weekend, and you have no chores there. You eat whatever you like (mom has food stamps), but it’s easy to be a parent two weekends a month. It’s harder to be a parent all the time.” 

I’ve never derogated their mother. I don’t want to cripple their image of her, but it’s frustrating as hell that they see her as this angel and don’t appreciate everything their stepmother and I do for them. 
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's see. The user is asking whether the person in the given scenario is in the wrong. The situation involves a father who's a stepdad now, dealing with his kids still idolizing their mother despite her past issues. He's providing for them, but feels resentful when they see their mom as a hero. 

First, I need to understand the key points. The ex-wife has a troubled history—jail time, affairs, job losses, lives with her mom. The stepdad and his new wife are the primary caregivers, handling all the financial and daily responsibilities. The daughter is preparing for a pageant and asks if she should say her mom is her hero. The stepdad responds by pointing out the other parent's limitations, but doesn't directly put her down.

The question is whether the stepdad is wrong. The user wants a yes or no answer based on the details. So, what factors determine this?

On one hand, the stepdad is frustrated and feels unappreciated. He's trying to help the daughter understand that their ex-mom's parenting isn't as robust. He's not outright badmouthing her, just highlighting the reality. But on the other hand, he's the one providing the actual resources and day-to-day care. The kids might not realize the effort involved.

But is it wrong for him to express his feelings in that way? He's trying to guide his daughter's perspective without being negative. He's pointing out facts—like the mother's limited support and his own family's efforts. However, maybe there's a better way to handle it without making the daughter feel conflicted. 

Also, he's not forbidding her from choosing her mom as a hero, just making her aware of the situation. The key here is that he's not directly criticizing the mother but explaining the circumstances. So, is that wrong? Or is it a valid expression of his frustration?

I think the key here is that he's not badmouthing the mother but providing context. He's trying to help his daughter make an informed choice by highlighting the realities of each parent's role. While his frustration is understandable, he's not acting out of malice. Therefore, he's not in the wrong. The answer is B.
